title: Train strike to go ahead this bank holiday weekend | West Country (W)
text:
A strike by workers at First Great Western is to go ahead this bank holiday after talks failed to reach an agreement.
Members of the Rail, Maritime and Transport union at First Great Western are due to walk out for three days from Saturday 29 August in a row over new trains.
The walk out will disrupt services on one of the busiest weekends of the year Credit: PA The action will disrupt FGW services, which run from London to South Wales and the South West.
The union is in dispute over new high speed trains which it says will hit jobs and on-board catering.
General secretary Mick Cash issued a circular to RMT union members saying urgent talks had been held with the company, but no agreement had been reached.
First Great Western say "positive talks" were held with the union on Tuesday 25 August.
We have once again reiterated that our proposals do not involve running the new trains without a qualified train manager on board and that our plans mean recruiting at least 100 more on-board staff, not less.
The brand new Super Express Trains will deliver more seats, faster journey times and more frequent journeys for our passengers.
Our plans mean more train managers and customer hosts on board our trains not less, and who on every Intercity Express Train, will maintain the same safety competences as they currently require.
